Origin of the Size-Dependent Stokes Shift in CsPbBr3 Perovskite
Nanocrystals
Michael C. Brennan,†,§ John E. Herr,†,§ Triet S. Nguyen-Beck,† Jessica Zinna,† Sergiu Draguta,†
Sergei Rouvimov,‡ John Parkhill,*,† and Masaru Kuno*,†
†Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Notre Dame, 251 Nieuwland Science Hall, Notre Dame, Indiana 46556,
United States
‡Notre Dame Integrated Imaging Facility, University of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, Indiana 46556, United States
*
S Supporting Information
ABSTRACT: The origin of the size-dependent Stokes shift in
CsPbBr3 nanocrystals (NCs) is explained for the ﬁrst time. Stokes shifts range from 82 to 20 meV for NCs with eﬀective
edge lengths varying from ∼4 to 13 nm.

question: Does this article have any supporting information?
gold_evidence_text:
For PL measurements, the excitation
wavelength was λexc = 350 nm. For band edge excitation measurements, λexc was set to the peak energy of each sample’s band edge
absorption. In PLE measurements, emission positions were taken on
the red edge of each sample’s band edge emission. PLE spectra were
corrected for wavelength-dependent variations of the lamp intensity. Photoluminescence Quantum Yield Measurements. PL QY
measurements were performed according to a standardized
procedure58 with appropriate organic dyes [coumarin 6 (QY =
78%)59 and coumarin 102 (QY = 74%)60 for the green and blue
regions of the spectrum, respectively] dissolved in ethanol (100%,
Sigma-Aldrich). The NC solvent was toluene. Optical densities were
below 0.2 for both dye and NC samples. Time-Correlated Single Photon Counting Time-Resolved Emission Spectroscopy.

TCSPC-TRES measurements were obtained with
a Horiba Jobin Yvon TCSPC spectrometer with a NanoLED 371 nm
excitation source. Time-resolved PL decays were measured over 120
nm in 2 nm increments. TCSPC-TRES spectra were constructed by
taking slices of PL decay series to obtain the spectrum at a given time
after photoexcitation. Note that the instrument response time is
approximately 300 ps. Optical densities were below 0.2 in all cases. Solvatochromism Measurements. Ensemble samples for solvatochromism experiments were dried via vacuum and were redispersed in
hexanes and chloroform. Absorption and emission spectra were
measured as described above. Excitation Intensity-Dependent Emission Measurements. NC
ensembles for excitation intensity (Iexc)-dependent emission measurements were spin coated onto glass substrates (VWR micro cover glass,
25 mm).

question: What characterization techniques are used to analyze the material?
reference_answer:
1) Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM)
2) Absorption Spectroscopy
3) Photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy
4) Photoluminescence Excitation (PLE) spectroscopy
5) Time-Correlated Single Photon Counting Time-Resolved Emission Spectroscopy (TCSPC-TRES)
6) Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD)
gold_evidence_text:
■EXPERIMENTAL SECTION
Synthesis and Puriﬁcation of CsPbBr3 NCs. Ensemble NC
samples were synthesized with average edge lengths ranging from l =
3.0 to 12.8 nm using a hot injection method previously reported by
Protesescu et al.7 Brieﬂy, 0.18 mmol of PbBr2 (99.999% trace metals
basis, Sigma-Aldrich) and 5 mL of octadecene (ODE, 90% technical
grade, Acros) were placed in a 10 mL three-neck ﬂask and degassed at
120 °C for 1 h. The reaction vessel was backﬁlled with N2. Then 1 mL
of oleylamine (80−90% C-18 content, Acros) and 1 mL of oleic acid
(90% technical grade, Sigma-Aldrich) were injected into it. The
temperature was raised to 130−200 °C in order to tune the size with
higher (lower) temperatures favoring larger (smaller) NCs. Once the
temperature stabilized, 1 mL of a Cs-oleate precursor solution (125
mM in ODE, prepared as described below) was injected.

The reaction
was then immediately quenched with an ice bath. The precipitate was
separated by centrifuging the suspension at 7500 rpm for 10 min and
was subsequently washed with a 4:1 mixture of toluene:acetone. Note
that the addition of too much acetone strips the surface ligands,
causing them to aggregate. NCs were then dispersed in toluene and
isolated using further centrifugation at 7500 rpm for 10 min. Recovered NCs were stored in toluene for further analysis. For
smaller NC ensembles (in the range of l ∼3−6 nm), reactions were
scaled up 10-fold, and the Cs-oleate precursor was injected at
temperatures between 130° and 140 °C. Cs-oleate was synthesized according to a previous report.7 Brieﬂy,
2.5 mmol of Cs2CO3 (99.9%, Sigma-Aldrich) was placed in a 100 mL
three neck ﬂask with 40 mL of ODE and 2.5 mL of oleic acid.

The
reaction mixture was degassed at 120 °C for 1 h and was then
backﬁlled with N2 and heated at 150 °C for 6−8 h. Cs-oleate exists as a
precipitate at room temperature and must be heated to 100 °C in
order to dissolve it prior to injection. Optical Measurements. Absorption Spectroscopy. Ensemble
absorption spectra were obtained on a Cary 50 Bio UV−vis
spectrophotometer. Spectra were recorded under ambient conditions
in a fused silica cuvette using dilute solutions of CsPbBr3 NCs in
toluene. Optical densities were <0.3 in all cases. Photoluminescence and Photoluminescence Excitation Spectroscopy. PL and PLE spectra were recorded under identical
conditions as absorption spectra using a Jobin Yvon Fluorolog-3. In
both PL and PLE measurements, excitation and emission slit widths
were set to 2 and 1 nm, respectively. The integration time was 0.25 s
with 1 nm increments.

question: Did the synthesis involve the use of vacuum?
gold_evidence_text:
To establish that the Stokes shift is independent of dielectric
media, we have additionally recorded absorption/emission
spectra in hexane and chloroform. Resulting Stokes shifts
quantitatively agree with values in Figure 2b and deviate by no
more than 10 meV across solvents. This is illustrated in Figure
S7a, which plots Stokes shift data from CsPbBr3 (ϵ∞= 4.96)7
NC ensembles dispersed in hexane, toluene, and chloroform
(associated static dielectric constants: ϵhex = 1.88, ϵtol = 2.38,
and ϵchlo = 4.81).40 The only observed solvent-dependent eﬀect
is a blueshift of absorption/emission spectra in toluene and
chloroform relative to that in hexane. This is summarized in
Figure S7b, which shows absorption/emission spectra of a l =
4.2 nm ensemble in the same three solvents.

question: What is the morphology and structure of halide perovskite?
reference_answer: CsPbBr3 adopt cuboidal morphologies and have surfaces passivated with oleylammonium and oleate ligands.
gold_evidence_text:
We
further illustrate that the emitting state possesses low cesium
character, likely providing insight into the PL properties of
analogous nanostructured lead halide perovskites (e.g.,
MAPbX3).
■RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
Nineteen CsPbBr3 NC ensembles were synthesized using the
technique described by Protesescu et al.7 Resulting NCs adopt
cuboidal morphologies and have surfaces passivated with
oleylammonium and oleate ligands.35 Figure 1 shows
representative low- and high-magniﬁcation TEM images of
four ensembles, which span the size series. The lowmagniﬁcation micrographs show that the NCs form close
packed areas with residual size distributions in the range of 5−
20%. Figure S1 illustrates sizing histograms from where
eﬀective edge lengths and size distributions have been obtained. Figure S2 illustrates an experimental sizing curve extracted from
the data.

explained. As a historical note, analogous size-dependent Stokes shifts
were observed two decades ago in colloidal CdSe quantum dots

absorption and bright in emission. Subsequently computed

agree with experimentally measured values. The study therefore
indicates that absorbing and emitting states are distinct in

shifts. At a broader level, since cesium orbitals do not
signiﬁcantly contribute to the CHS, this state is likely a general

This is
consistent with previously described ﬁne structure for MAPbBr3
and MAPbI3.57 Figure 4c (left) summarizes the energetic
ordering of resulting ﬁne structure states and depicts relevant
absorption and emission transitions within a ﬁne structure
descriptor of CsPbBr3 NCs. The calculations reveal that the
magnitude of any spin−orbit induced ﬁne structure splitting
(ESOC) ranges from 10.3 meV for a l = 2.64 nm NC to 0.13
meV for a l = 3.82 nm NC. Triplet/singlet ﬁne structure
splitting is therefore negligible for experimentally relevant sizes
(i.e., ∼4−13 nm). We conclude that ﬁne structure SOC/
electron−hole exchange cannot explain observed size-dependent ΔEs values. In what follows, we therefore do not invoke ﬁne
structure when rationalizing observed Stokes shifts.

Supporting Information
ABSTRACT: Light emitting lead halide perovskite nanocrystals
are currently emerging as the workhorse in quantum dot research. Most of these reported nanocrystals are isotropic cubes or
polyhedral; but anisotropic nanostructures with controlled
anisotropic directions still remain a major challenge. For
orthorhombic CsPbBr3, the 1D shaped nanostructures reported
are linear and along either of the axial directions ⟨100⟩. In contrast,
herein, spiral CsPbBr3 perovskite nanorods in the orthorhombic
phase are reported with unusual anisotropy having (101) planes
remaining perpendicular to the major axis [201].

gold_evidence_text:
Tetrabutylammonium hexaﬂuorophosphate (TBAPF6) was purchased
from TCI Chemicals. Solvents are purchased from Finer India. All
chemicals were used without any further puriﬁcation. Methods. Preparation of Cs-Oleate Stock Solution. Cs-oleate
solution was prepared following literature reported method.1 In a
typical synthesis, 1.2 mmol (390 mg) of Cs2CO3 and 2 mL of OA
were taken in a three-neck round-bottom ﬂask along with 18 mL of
ODE, purged with nitrogen for 1 h at 120 °C, and then the
temperature was increased to 150 °C for obtaining a clear Cs-oleate
solution. This was further annealed for another 10 min, and then the
solution was collected under hot conditions and stored in deaerated
vial. Since Cs-oleate solidiﬁed at room temperature, it was preheated
to 80 °C before using in the reactions. Synthesis of Cs2CdBr4 Nanorods.

Cesium cadmium bromide
nanorods were synthesized by injection of Cs-oleate into a mixture of
Cd-precursor, OA, OLA, and phenacyl bromide following a hotinjection protocol. In a typical synthesis, 0.2 mmol of CdO (25.6 mg),
0.6 mmol of phenacyl bromide (119.4 mg), 1 mL of OA, and 5 mL of
ODE were loaded in a 25 mL round bottomed ﬂask and deaerated at
120 °C for 1 h by purging nitrogen gas. Then the temperature was
raised to 220 °C and 0.5 mL OLA was injected. The solution became
red initially, then orange, and ﬁnally yellow with 15 min of annealing. After that, the temperature was decreased to 120 °C and 0.5 mL of
Cs-oleate solution was swiftly injected into the yellow solution and
annealed for 3 min. Finally, the reaction was ice quenched by dipping
the reaction ﬂask in an ice−water bath.

These nanocrystals were
further centrifuged at 3000 rpm for 5 min and precipitated
nanocrystals were redispersed in deaerated octadecene (1 mL) for
further use. Synthesis of CsPbBr3 Nanorods. CsPbBr3 nanorods were
synthesized by injecting Cs2CdBr4 nanorods solution in the reaction
mixture containing Pb(II), phenacyl bromide along with OA and
OLA. With diﬀerent annealing times, the obtained nanorods were
labeled as A, B, C, and D as presented in Figure 1. In a typical
synthesis, 0.2 mmol of PbO (44 mg), 0.6 mmol of phenacyl bromide
(119.4 mg), 1 mL of OA, and 5 mL of ODE were loaded in a 25 mL
round bottomed ﬂask and deaerated at 120 °C for 1 h by purging
nitrogen gas. Then, the temperature was raised to 220 °C and 0.5 mL
OLA was injected and annealed. The solution initially turned red to
orange and then yellow within 15 min.

question: What amounts of solvent used in the synthesis?
gold_evidence_text:
Photoreduction of CO2 was
carried out in a closed glass shell reactor in CO2 saturated ethyl
acetate and water mixture. In a typical procedure, 10 mL of ethyl
acetate and water (300:1, v/v) mixture was taken in the glass shell
reactor and heated to 120 °C for 2 min in order to form solid vapor
interface. After cooling down to room temperature, approximately 5
mg of the CsPbBr3 nanorod photocatalysts in 1 mL ethyl acetate were
introduced into the glass shell reactor. Then, CO2 gas was purged to 1
bar initially for 30 min to remove other contained gases and further
continued to another 30 min for saturation. A 450 W Xe arc lamp
with a calibrated intensity of 150 mW/cm2 served as the light source
during the photocatalytic measurements.

from TCI Chemicals. Solvents are purchased from Finer India. All
chemicals were used without any further puriﬁcation. Methods. Preparation of Cs-Oleate Stock Solution. Cs-oleate
solution was prepared following literature reported method.1 In a
typical synthesis, 1.2 mmol (390 mg) of Cs2CO3 and 2 mL of OA
were taken in a three-neck round-bottom ﬂask along with 18 mL of
ODE, purged with nitrogen for 1 h at 120 °C, and then the
temperature was increased to 150 °C for obtaining a clear Cs-oleate
solution. This was further annealed for another 10 min, and then the
solution was collected under hot conditions and stored in deaerated
vial. Since Cs-oleate solidiﬁed at room temperature, it was preheated
to 80 °C before using in the reactions. Synthesis of Cs2CdBr4 Nanorods.

gold_evidence_text:
A 450 W Xe arc lamp from Newport with
calibrated intensity 150 mW/cm2 served as light source during the
catalytic measurements. The gaseous products were detected by
TRACE 1110, Thermo Scientiﬁc online gas chromatograph using
thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and ﬂame ionization detector
(FID) in a series. Biologic, SP 300 workstation was used for the
electrochemical measurement.
■RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
For the synthesis of spiral CsPbBr3 perovskite nanorods, the
prelattice of a parent material Cs2CdBr4 was explored for
Pb(II) insertion. Hence, the synthesis process was followed in
two steps; ﬁrst orthorhombic phase Cs2CdBr4 nanorods were
synthesized and then, in the second stage, these nanorods were
injected into the Pb(II) reaction system for obtaining the
desired nanostructures.

question: What type of article is it? Is it a review, research, or another category altogether?
gold_evidence_text:
In particular, the recent success of
organometallic halide perovskites in photovoltaic devices has
triggered research activities on inorganic halide perovskite
nanocrystals (NCs) due to their good stability, ultrahigh
photoluminescence (PL) quantum yield, and compositiondependent luminescence with a wide color gamut.2−4 The
cesium lead bromide (CsPbBr3) perovskites deliver outstanding
optoelectronic properties and are signiﬁcantly more stable than
organic−inorganic hybrid perovskite compounds. Restricting
the physical dimensions of the CsPbBr3 perovskite crystallites
to a nanometer region would further unlock spatial conﬁnement eﬀects. This change allows large spectral tunability, thus
facilitating the band-gap optimization for the devices.5−10
Pressure, as a unique thermodynamic variable, provides a
powerful means to study the structural and electronic behaviors
of MHP materials.

The schematic diagram of the
lifetime measurement is shown in Figure S4. In principle, the
observed lifetime proﬁles are the convolutional results of the
real decay curves and the instrumental response function (IRF)
to extract the time constant. The width of the IRF is generally
determined to be less than 1 ns, thereby greatly facilitating the
data ﬁtting. As the external pressure approached about 1.03
GPa, the carrier lifetime ﬁtted with an exponential formula
underwent an obvious increase of ∼19% from 12.6 ns at
ambience, implying a pressure-driven decrease in oscillator
strength that agrees well with the changes of PL intensity
(Figure 4a). Detailed lifetime data and the corresponding errors
of CsPbBr3 nanocrystals under diﬀerent pressure points are
shown in Table S1.

question: What reagents are used?
reference_answer:
1) cesium carbonate (Cs2CO3, Sigma-Aldrich, 99.9%)
2) oleic acid (Sigma-Aldrich, 90%)
3) octadecene (Sigma-Aldrich, 90%)
4) PbBr2 (Sigma-Aldrich, 98%)
5) oleylamine (OLA, Sigma-Aldrich, 70%)
6) Toluene
gold_evidence_text:
The targeted
CsPbBr3 NCs were synthesized according to the modulated colloidal
chemistry method.6 In a typical synthesis, cesium carbonate (0.407 g,
Cs2CO3, Sigma-Aldrich, 99.9%) and oleic acid (1.2 mL, OA, SigmaAldrich, 90%) together with octadecene (20 mL, ODE, Sigma-Aldrich,
90%) were loaded in a 50 mL three-neck ﬂask. After drying for 1 h at
120 °C, the solvent was heated under N2 to 150 °C until all CsCO3
powders were dissolved, indicating the formation of a Cs-oleate
complex. Then, Cs-oleate was cooled to 100 °C before injection. Subsequently, 5 mL of ODE, 0.069 g of PbBr2 (Sigma-Aldrich, 98%),
0.5 mL of oleylamine (OLA, Sigma-Aldrich, 70%), and 0.5 mL of OA
were loaded in a 50 mL three-neck ﬂask. The mixture was heated to
120 °C with strong stirring and remained for 1 h under N2.

After
complete solubilization of PbBr2, the temperature was raised to 170
°C, and the Cs-oleate solution (0.5 mL) was quickly injected. About

centrifuging for 5 min at 10 000 rpm. The resulting samples were
characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), highresolution TEM, high-angle annular dark-ﬁeld scanning transmission
electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images, and elemental mapping
performed on a JEM-2200FS with an emission gun operating at 200
kV. In Situ High-Pressure Optical Experiments. All of the in situ
high-pressure experiments shown in this study were carried out with a
symmetric DAC apparatus. IIa-type ultralow ﬂuorescence diamonds
with a culet size of 300 μm were used.

question: What is the morphology and structure of halide perovskite?
reference_answer: CsPbBr3 Nanocrystals have a nanocube morphology with good crystallinity. Elemental mapping indicates that the elements Cs, Pb, and Br are homogeneously distributed throughout the whole sample.
gold_evidence_text:
The
convergence thresholds were set at values of 5.0 e−6 eV/atom for
energy and 10−2 eV Å−1 for force. The partial density of states (DOSs)
of isolated atoms were collected by adopting the identical
pseudopotential of the GGA that is implemented in the Vienna ab
initio simulation package (VASP).32
■RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
The morphology and structure of the synthesized CsPbBr3
NCs were investigated using TEM and HRTEM characterizations. As shown in Figure 1a and b, the samples before
compression exhibit a nanocube morphology with good
crystallinity. Elemental mapping indicates that the elements
Cs, Pb, and Br are homogeneously distributed throughout the
whole sample, which suggests high purity of the ﬁnal products
(Figure 1c). The corresponding size distribution of obtained
CsPbBr3 NCs with Gauss ﬁtting is depicted in Figure S1.

question: What is the shape and crystalline phase of the synthesized material?
reference_answer:
Nanocrystals, isostructural phase
transition under the pressure
gold_evidence_text:
In this study, high pressure is introduced to tailor
the optical and structural properties of MHP-based cesium
lead bromide nanocrystals (CsPbBr3 NCs), which exhibit
excellent thermodynamic stability. Both the pressure-dependent steady-state photoluminescence and absorption spectra
experience a stark discontinuity at ∼1.2 GPa, where an isostructural phase transformation regarding the Pbnm space group
occurs. The physical origin points to the repulsive force impact due to the overlap between the valence electron charge clouds of
neighboring layers. Simultaneous band-gap narrowing and carrier-lifetime prolongation of CsPbBr3 trihalide perovskite NCs were
also achieved as expected, which facilitates the broader solar spectrum absorption for photovoltaic applications.

A CsPbBr3 Perovskite Quantum Dot/Graphene Oxide Composite for
Photocatalytic CO2 Reduction
Yang-Fan Xu,†
Mu-Zi Yang,† Bai-Xue Chen, Xu-Dong Wang, Hong-Yan Chen, Dai-Bin Kuang,*
and Cheng-Yong Su
MOE Key Laboratory of Bioinorganic and Synthetic Chemistry, Lehn Institute of Functional Materials, School of Chemistry, Sun
Yat-sen University, Guangzhou 510275, P. R. China
*
S Supporting Information
ABSTRACT: Halide perovskite quantum dots (QDs),
primarily regarded as optoelectronic materials for LED and
photovoltaic devices, have not been applied for photochemical conversion (e.g., water splitting or CO2
reduction) applications because of their insuﬃcient
stability in the presence of moisture or polar solvents. Herein, we report the use of CsPbBr3 QDs as novel
photocatalysts to convert CO2 into solar fuels in
nonaqueous media.

A CsPbBr3 Perovskite Quantum Dot/Graphene Oxide Composite for
Photocatalytic CO2 Reduction
Yang-Fan Xu,†
Mu-Zi Yang,† Bai-Xue Chen, Xu-Dong Wang, Hong-Yan Chen, Dai-Bin Kuang,*
and Cheng-Yong Su
MOE Key Laboratory of Bioinorganic and Synthetic Chemistry, Lehn Institute of Functional Materials, School of Chemistry, Sun
Yat-sen University, Guangzhou 510275, P. R. China
*
S Supporting Information
ABSTRACT: Halide perovskite quantum dots (QDs),
primarily regarded as optoelectronic materials for LED and
photovoltaic devices, have not been applied for photochemical conversion (e.g., water splitting or CO2
reduction) applications because of their insuﬃcient
stability in the presence of moisture or polar solvents. Herein, we report the use of CsPbBr3 QDs as novel
photocatalysts to convert CO2 into solar fuels in
nonaqueous media.

question: What type of article is it? Is it a review, research, or another category altogether?
gold_evidence_text:
Recent and rapid developments in organic−inorganic halide perovskite materials have
triggered great interest among researchers for their optoelectronic applications, especially in photovoltaic devices, because
of the high extinction coeﬃcients, wide absorption ranges, and
long electron−hole diﬀusion lengths of these materials.14−16
Remarkable photoelectric conversion eﬃciencies have been
achieved for perovskite solar cells (PSCs) within just a few
years of research (from 3.8% to 22.1%).17 Inspired from the
achievements in solar cells, halide perovskite materials are
strong candidates for conducting eﬃcient photosynthesis if the
extreme characteristic instability issues of halide perovskite
materials can be resolved ﬁrst.18,19 Recently, for the ﬁrst time,

gold_evidence_text:
Nam et al. reported that methylammonium lead iodide
(MAPbI3) powder could drive the photocatalytic splitting of HI
for hydrogen (H2) evolution and that MAPbI3 was stable in a
series of saturated aqueous solutions after precisely controlling
the ion concentrations (H+ and I−).20
Herein, we focus on CsPbBr3, a typical halide perovskite
material with competing optoelectronic properties but
preferable stability when compared to its organic−inorganic
hybrid counterparts.21 Both CsPbBr3 quantum dots (QDs) and
a CsPbBr3 QD/graphene oxide (CsPbBr3 QD/GO) composite
were designed for the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 to ethyl
acetate (as depicted in Figure 1). To the best of our knowledge,
this is the ﬁrst report on artiﬁcial photosynthesis based on
halide perovskite QDs.

The
amperometric I−t curves (Figure 5a) plotted at −0.4 VAg/AgCl
demonstrated that the photocurrent was highly repeatable upon
cycling the light on and oﬀ. The photocurrent response of the
CsPbBr3 QD/GO sample was 54 μA cm−2, corresponding to a
28.57% enhancement compared to the CsPbBr3 QDs (42 μA
cm−2), which agrees with the Relectron in the photocatalytic
characterizations. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy
(EIS) was further employed to detect the charge-transport
behaviors of these two electrodes. As shown in Figure 5b, the
Nyquist plots indicated that the charge-transfer resistance
obviously decreased for the CsPbBr3 QD/GO ﬁlm, as
evidenced by the smaller semicircle arc at high frequencies
and the corresponding ﬁtting results (10 238 ohms for CsPbBr3
QDs and 5387 ohms for CsPbBr3 QD/GO).

question: What medium was used for storing and analysis?
gold_evidence_text:
The high-resolution plots of Cs 3d,
Pb 4f, and Br 3d (Figure S5) demonstrated that their respective
binding energies were in accordance with those presented in
previous reports23,24 and were unchanged after introducing
GO. Notably, Br-rich surfaces were observed, as concluded
from the surface atomic ratios summarized in Table S1, which
may result in a self-passivation eﬀect to alleviate the surface
states.23 To evaluate the mass ratio of QDs to GO,
thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed. The GO
mass ratio in the composite was ∼8.73% according to the TGA
plots in Figure S6. The as-prepared CsPbBr3 QDs and CsPbBr3 QD/GO
composite were used as photocatalysts for artiﬁcial CO2
reduction.

question: What is the morphology and structure of halide perovskite?
reference_answer:
CsPbBr3 QDs have the spherical shape, a lattice spacing of 0.2814 nm,
corresponding to the (220) plane, which revealed that the CsPbBr3 particles were highly crystalline.
CsPbBr3 QDs were evenly distributed on the GO sheets and the energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) mappings of Cs, Pb, Br, and C showed uniform dispersion of the CsPbBr3 QDs on GO.
gold_evidence_text:
sessed visible-light absorption behavior and had strong
photoinduced luminescence under UV-light stimulation, as
depicted in Figure S1a and S1b. The powder X-ray diﬀraction
(PXRD) patterns (Figure S1c) demonstrated that all the peaks
of the as-prepared samples were indexed to the pure
orthorhombic phase, and the broadened peaks indicated the
reduction of the particle sizes. The transmission electron
microscopy (TEM) image in Figure 2a shows the spherical
shape of the CsPbBr3 QDs with sizes of approximately 6 ± 1
nm, according to the size distribution statistics in Figure S2. As
shown in the inset of Figure 2a, a lattice spacing of 0.2814 nm,
corresponding to the (220) plane, was clearly observed, which
revealed that the CsPbBr3 particles were highly crystalline.

The
TEM images of the as-prepared GO are shown in Figure S3,
demonstrating a sheet-like morphology and characteristic
graphitization at the edges. The Raman spectrum (Figure S4)
of the as-prepared GO displayed two prominent peaks, the D
band (1599 cm−1) and G band (1360 cm−1), with a peak height
ratio (ID/IG) of 1.27. After introducing GO, the CsPbBr3 QDs
were evenly distributed on the GO sheets (Figure 2b). The size
and crystallinity of the CsPbBr3 QDs remained identical, as
concluded from the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image in
Figure 2c and the statistics in Figure S2b. Moreover, the
energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) mappings of Cs, Pb, Br, and C
further conﬁrmed the existence and uniform dispersion of the
CsPbBr3 QDs on GO. Furthermore, X-ray photoelectron
spectroscopy (XPS) characterizations were performed to
characterize the surface.

gold_evidence_text:
Furthermore, the normalized timeresolved PL decay plots after pulsed laser excitation at λ = 369.6
nm (Figure 4b) conﬁrmed the fast charge separation by
graphene. The decay traces were ﬁtted using triexponential
decay kinetics with low uncertainties (χ), and the parameters
are listed in Table 2. Both the CsPbBr3 QDs and the CsPbBr3
QD/GO composite exhibited a PL decay time on the
nanosecond scale, which are consistent with previous
reports.22,34 The CsPbBr3 QD/GO composite decayed
distinctly faster than the pristine CsPbBr3 QDs, with average
PL decay times (τaverage) of 11.3 and 38.3 ns for the CsPbBr3
QD/GO composite and the CsPbBr3 QDs, respectively.

μmol/g h was observed for the CsPbBr3 QD/GO composite. These rates are superior to those of CdS and other newly
developed photocatalysts with visible-light responses under Xelamp illumination (Table S1). Notably, the selectivity for CO2
reduction was impressively greater than 99%, implying the
eﬃcient suppression of the H2 evolution reaction in the
nonaqueous solvent. However, part of the CO yield potentially
originates from the partial photooxidation of ethyl acetate,
which was evidenced via a control experiment using an inert N2
instead of a saturated CO2 atmosphere.

question: What are the parameters of the source in photocatalysis?
reference_answer:
Xe lamp 100 W
solar spectrum condition AM 1.5G filter
light intensity
150 mW/ cm2
gold_evidence_text:
QD photocatalysts have attracted widespread
attention because of their high surface areas and short
charge-transfer pathways.25 Moreover, the enlarged bandgap
and shifted band position caused by quantum-size conﬁnement26 can provide more potential energy to suﬃciently drive
photochemical reactions. In this study, the CO2 reduction
experiments were conducted in a sealed Pyrex bottle with ethyl
acetate as the solvent. Ethyl acetate was selected because its
mild polarity can stabilize the CsPbBr3 QDs and because CO2
is highly soluble in ethyl acetate (e.g., 241.0 mM, which is more
than 7 times the solubility of CO2 in water).27 Light was
provided by a 100-W Xe lamp with an AM 1.5G ﬁlter to
simulate solar light illumination. Figure 3 and Table 1 present
the amounts of CH4 and H2 produced after 12 h of
photocatalytic CO2 reduction.

Transient current measurement also supported Fe(II) doped 
nanocrystals as better photoconductor and showed superior photoresponse compared to it

samples, it was established that doping in CsPbBr3 indeed enhanced the catalytic activities of 
these nanocrystals. These results with selective CH4 and CO as major product for doped and 
undoped nanocrystals were further correlated with their adsorption and desorption abilities onto

Perovskite nanocrystals have emerged as one of the most efficient light harvesting materials in 
current research.1-7 For light to light energy conversion, these have been extensively studied and 
as high as near unity photoluminescence quantum yields in different colors were established.5, 814 However, being efficient light absorbing material, their utilizations in light to chemical energy 
transfer are limited.15-17 Major obstacles of these nanocrystals are their sensitivity towards polar 
environments and the strong recombination possibility of the photogenerated charge carriers.3, 
18, 19 Hence, unlike chalcogenide quantum dots, implementations of these nanocrystals in 
catalysis is less explored.

From the plot, it was evident that the photocurrent was repeatable with light 
on-off cycles. The maximum PEC photocurrent density -120 µA cm-2 observed for Fe(II) doped 
CsPbBr3 (25% Fe loading w.r.t. Pb)nanocrystal which was 3.15 times enhancement than undoped 
nanocrystals (38 µA cm-2). Figure 3e presents the chronoamperometric I-t plots of the 
photoelectrodes using different percentage of Fe(II) doped CsPbBr3 nanocrystals and measured 
at -0.4V vs Ag/AgCl. The photocurrent density observed gradually increased from 0-25% and then 
decreased with higher doping percentage. This change in the trend was also found in good 
agreement with photocatalytic CO2 reduction efficiency (Figure S2). PEC impedance spectra were 
measured to detect the charge-transport behavior of prepared electrodes and shown in Figure 
3f.

question: What products are formed during the photocatalytic process?
gold_evidence_text:
The 
predominated products CO (4.6 µmol g-1 h-1) and CH4 (1.9 µmol g-1 h-1) were obtained for 
undoped CsPbBr3 nanocrystal, which were also shown in previous reports (Table S1).17, 19, 
20However, doped nanocrystals predominantly formed CH4 in comparison to CO. In optimized Fe 
doping (loading 25% with respect to Pb), the maximum amount of CH4 (6.1 µmol g-1 h-1) was 
evolved over CO (3.2 µmol g-1 h-1). Moreover, addition of excess Fe amount was harmful to the 
photocatalytic performance, resulting in lowering the amount of product formation which was 
shown in Figure S2. Corresponding energy dispersive spectra (EDS) and elemental compositions 
are shown in Figure S3.

ABSTRACT: The construction of an S-scheme heterojunction is recognized
as a promising approach to developing eﬃcient photocatalytic systems. Herein,
a novel S-scheme heterojunction of CsPbBr3 nanocrystals/CoAl layered
double hydroxide (LDH) nanosheets was fabricated and applied for
photocatalytic conversion of CO2. CsPbBr3/CoAl-LDH composites exhibited
superior activity for CO2 photoreduction under visible light.

gold_evidence_text:
Recently, the halide perovskite nanocrystals (NCs) have
emerged as strong candidates for photocatalytic applications
owing to their high extinction coeﬃcients, broad absorption
ranges, and appropriate band positions.27−29 In particular, the
typical all-inorganic perovskite material CsPbBr3 has aroused
the most intense interest on account of its relatively robust
stability against humidity and high temperature.30,31 However,
as in the case of other single-component photocatalysts like
LDHs, pristine perovskite CsPbBr3 suﬀers from severe
electron−hole radiative recombination, which makes it exhibit
unsatisfactory performance in CO2 photoreduction.32−34 So
far, great eﬀorts have been made to construct CsPbBr3-based
heterojunctions with superior photocatalytic performance,
including the traditional type-II heterojunctions such as
CsPbBr3/g-C3N4,35 P3HT/CsPbBr3,36 CsPbBr3/UiO-66-
(NH2),37 and CsPbBr3/MoS2
38 and Z-scheme heterojunctions
including α-Fe2O3/CsPbBr3
39 and CsPbBr3/Bi2WO6,40,41 as
well as the newly emerged S-scheme heterojunction of TiO2/
CsPbBr3,42,43 BiVO4/CsPbBr3,44 WO3/CsPbBr3,45 CsPbBr3
/BiOBr,46 etc.

However, the fabrication of the S-scheme
heterojunction of CsPbBr3/LDHs and its application in
photocatalytic CO2 reduction have not been reported. In
view of the advantages of each component, it is anticipated that
the combination of CsPbBr3 and LDHs will yield an eﬃcient
photocatalyst for CO2 reduction. In the present work, motivated by the high oxidation
potential of CoAl-LDH, more negative reduction potential of
CsPbBr3, and strong visible-light-harvesting capability of both
components, we constructed a novel CsPbBr3/CoAl-LDH
composite photocatalyst for CO2 reduction. Based on various
characterization techniques such as X-ray photoelectron
spectra (XPS), Mott−Schottky (M−S) plots, and electron
spin resonance (ESR), an S-scheme charge transfer mode
between CsPbBr3 and CoAl-LDH was validated.

Beneﬁtting
from the eﬃcient charge separation and retainment of the
strongly reductive electrons, the resultant CsPbBr3/CoAl-LDH
composite exhibited remarkable photocatalytic activity toward
CO2 reduction. Finally, the mechanism of enhancing the
photocatalytic activity was thoroughly discussed.
■EXPERIMENTAL SECTION
Chemicals. Co(NO3)2·6H2O (99%), Al(NO3)3·9H2O (99.99%),
Cs2CO3 (99.9%), PbBr2 (99%), urea (≥99%), oleic acid (OA, ≥90%),
oleylamine (OAm, ≥90%), 1-octadecene (ODE, ≥90%), ethyl acetate
(EA, 99%), tetrabutylammonium hexaﬂuorophosphate (TBAPF6,
98%), ethanol (99.5%), and hexane (99%) were all obtained from
Shanghai TITAN Technology Co., Ltd. and used as received. Synthesis of CoAl-LDH. CoAl-LDH was prepared by a
hydrothermal method as follows: Co(NO3)2·6H2O (2.183 g),
Al(NO3)3·9H2O (0.938 g), and urea (3.003 g) were added to 80
mL of deionized water.

question: What medium was used for storing and analysis?
gold_evidence_text:
The photoelectrochemical tests were carried out on a CHI 650E workstation (Shanghai
Chenhua) using the three-electrode conﬁguration. The assembled
photoelectrodes (CPB/LDH, CoAl-LDH, and CsPbBr3 NCs on FTO
glass) were used as the working electrode, while Pt mesh and
saturated Ag/AgCl were selected as the counter electrode and the
reference electrode, respectively. The working electrodes were
fabricated by spin-coating the previously prepared slurry (CPB/
LDH, CoAl-LDH, or CsPbBr3 NCs dispersed in the mixture of
hexane and Naﬁon solution) on FTO glass. Next, 0.1 M TBAPF6 in
an EA solution was applied as an electrolyte and a 300 W Xe lamp (λ
> 420 nm) was used as a visible-light source. Photocatalytic Activity Measurements. In the photocatalytic
CO2 reduction reaction, 8 mg of the photocatalyst was put into the
reactor containing 30 mL of EA and 100 μL of deionized water.

question: What is the morphology and structure of halide perovskite?
reference_answer:
The pristine CsPbBr3 NCs are orthorhombic crystal with a distinct interplanar spacing of 0.58 nm,
corresponding to the (110) lattice plane. the LDH exhibited a nanosheet structure with lattice fringes of 0.26 nm, which was assigned to the (012) plane. In CPB/LDH
composite CsPbBr3 NCs were decorated on the surface of the LDH nanosheet and integrated with LDH faultlessly to construct a heterostructure. The element mapping in indicated that the entire composite contained Cs, Pb, Br, Co, Al, and O elements with uniform dispersion.

question: What is the material used for photocatalysis?
gold_evidence_text:
The composite
containing 60 wt % CsPbBr3 displayed the optimal photocatalytic performance, which was enhanced by 2.6 and 9.9 times compared to CsPbBr3 and
CoAl-LDH, respectively. Moreover, this composite also showed stable
photocatalytic activity with no detectable decrease after four cycles. The
formation of an S-scheme heterojunction can promote the electron−hole
separation and provide a higher redox potential of the composite, thus leading
to the remarkable photocatalytic performance toward CO2 reduction. This
study provides a new perspective for designing and manufacturing perovskite-based S-scheme photocatalytic systems for CO2
reduction.

question: Is the system photocatalytic or photoelectrocatalytic?
gold_evidence_text:
The eﬀective
charge transport and retarded charge recombination can
endow the CPB/LDH composite with numerous free carriers
to participate in the photocatalytic reactions, which accounted
for the enhanced photocatalytic activity of the CPB/LDH
composite. According to the above characterizations and analyses, the
mechanism for the enhanced photocatalytic activity and
stability of the CPB/LDH composite was explained as follows:
due to their narrow band gaps, both CsPbBr3 and CoAl-LDH
could be induced to generate e−/h+ pairs under visible
excitation. Since the ECB and Ef of CoAl-LDH are lower than
those of CsPbBr3, spontaneous electron ﬂow from CsPbBr3 to
CoAl-LDH would occur upon intimate contact, resulting in the
creation of IEF directing from CsPbBr3 to CoAl-LDH and
band bending at the interface.

Shanghai TITAN Technology Co., Ltd. and used as received. Synthesis of CoAl-LDH. CoAl-LDH was prepared by a
hydrothermal method as follows: Co(NO3)2·6H2O (2.183 g),
Al(NO3)3·9H2O (0.938 g), and urea (3.003 g) were added to 80
mL of deionized water.

question: What is the amount of catalyst used for photocatalysis?
gold_evidence_text:
The photoelectrochemical tests were carried out on a CHI 650E workstation (Shanghai
Chenhua) using the three-electrode conﬁguration. The assembled
photoelectrodes (CPB/LDH, CoAl-LDH, and CsPbBr3 NCs on FTO
glass) were used as the working electrode, while Pt mesh and
saturated Ag/AgCl were selected as the counter electrode and the
reference electrode, respectively. The working electrodes were
fabricated by spin-coating the previously prepared slurry (CPB/
LDH, CoAl-LDH, or CsPbBr3 NCs dispersed in the mixture of
hexane and Naﬁon solution) on FTO glass. Next, 0.1 M TBAPF6 in
an EA solution was applied as an electrolyte and a 300 W Xe lamp (λ
> 420 nm) was used as a visible-light source. Photocatalytic Activity Measurements. In the photocatalytic
CO2 reduction reaction, 8 mg of the photocatalyst was put into the
reactor containing 30 mL of EA and 100 μL of deionized water.

was used as the main solvent because of its mild polarity to stabilize
CsPbBr3 NCs and high solubility for CO2. A 300 W Xe lamp with a
UV-cut ﬁlter (λ > 420 nm) loaded vertically above the reactor was
used as a visible-light source. Prior to irradiation, the system was
degassed to remove air from the reactor and ﬁlled with high-purity
CO2 gas. The formed products were collected for subsequent analysis
by gas chromatography (GC9700, Fuli Analytical Instrument Co.,
Ltd.).
■RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
Crystal structures of CsPbBr3 NCs, CoAl-LDH, and their
composites were investigated by XRD, as shown in Figure 2a. For pristine CsPbBr3 NCs, the locations of all diﬀraction peaks
were consistent with JCPDS No. 18-0364, which conﬁrmed
the formation of an orthorhombic crystal structure.

gold_evidence_text:

and restored at higher reduction/oxidation potentials, which
would endow remarkable photocatalytic performance of the
CPB/LDH composite. To evaluate the photocatalytic properties of the fabricated
CPB/LDH composites, the photoreduction of CO2 was carried
out under visible light. For all of the samples evaluated, CO
was identiﬁed as the main product, accompanied by a small
amount of CH4 (Figure S2). Figure 6a compares the total
yields of CO and CH4 over CoAl-LDH, CsPbBr3 NCs, and the
CPB/LDH composites after 4 h of a photoreaction. For
original CoAl-LDH, the yield of CO was only 5.6 μmol·g−1,
with negligible production of CH4, which was due to the rapid
recombination of charge carriers.

Solitary CsPbBr3 also
displayed poor photocatalytic activity, although its gaseous
product yields were a little higher compared to CoAl-LDH. However, the integration of these two components could
aﬀord glorious photocatalytic performance, suggesting that the
interaction between CsPbBr3 NCs and CoAl-LDH nanosheets
was conducive to enhancing the CO2 conversion eﬃciency. Especially, when the mass percentage of CsPbBr3 was 60 wt %,
the resultant sample exhibited the optimal photocatalytic
activity, with a total yield of up to 59.5 μmol·g−1 (51.9 μmol·
g−1 for CO and 7.6 μmol·g−1 for CH4), which was 9.9-fold
enhanced compared to LDH and 2.6-fold compared to
CsPbBr3. When further increasing the ratio of CsPbBr3, a
decreased performance was observed, which may be due to the
phenomenon that excessive CsPbBr3 would occupy the
reactive sites of CoAl-LDH.

gold_evidence_text:
The composite
containing 60 wt % CsPbBr3 displayed the optimal photocatalytic performance, which was enhanced by 2.6 and 9.9 times compared to CsPbBr3 and
CoAl-LDH, respectively. Moreover, this composite also showed stable
photocatalytic activity with no detectable decrease after four cycles. The
formation of an S-scheme heterojunction can promote the electron−hole
separation and provide a higher redox potential of the composite, thus leading
to the remarkable photocatalytic performance toward CO2 reduction. This
study provides a new perspective for designing and manufacturing perovskite-based S-scheme photocatalytic systems for CO2
reduction.

question: What is the averaged electron consumption rate for the reduced product?
reference_answer:
CsPbBr3/ CoAl-LDH 41.2 μmol/g h
LDH 3.7 μmol/g h

gold_evidence_text:
Therefore, 0.6 CPB/LDH was
determined to be the optimal proportion of this composite
photocatalyst. In addition, the averaged electron consumption
rate (Relectron) can reﬂect the number of eﬀective electrons
participating in the CO2 photoreduction, which can be
calculated by the formula Relectron = 2R(CO) + 8R(CH4). Hence, the Relectron of 0.6 CPB/LDH was calculated to be 41.2
μmol g−1 h−1, which was much higher compared to pristine
LDH and CsPbBr3 (3.7 and 17.6 μmol g−1 h−1, respectively). Since the reusability of a photocatalyst is a pivotal factor
determining its practical application, we evaluated the stability
of the CPB/LDH composite through four cycles of experiments. Figure 6b shows the corresponding yields of CO and
CH4 after four cycles of photocatalytic CO2 reduction.

Supporting Information
ABSTRACT: Transition-metal chalcogenides (TMCs) have received enormous attention by virtue of their large light absorption
coefficient, abundant catalytically active sites, and markedly
reduced spatially vectorial charge-transfer distance originating
from generic structural merits. However, the controllable
construction of TMC-based heterostructured photosystems for
photocatalytic carbon dioxide (CO2) reduction is retarded by the
ultrashort charge lifetime, sluggish charge-transfer kinetics, and low
target product selectivity.

TiO2, Cu2O, WO3, Bi2WO6, etc.), nitrides (e.g., C3N4, GaN,

lifetime of photoinduced charge carriers, remain as the pivotal
challenges of a CO2 photoreduction catalysis technique along
with poor selectivity and low conversion efficiency.19−22 Twodimensional (2D) transition-metal chalcogenide (TMC; CdS,

structure.23,24 Exploration of TMC-based photosystems has

The construction of a CdIn2S4/CsPbBr3 heterostructure is
depicted in Scheme 1. First, a hot-injection method was
utilized to prepare CsPbBr3 QDs, and CdIn2S4 NSs were
fabricated by a one-pot approach. The tailor-made positively
charged CsPbBr3 QDs and negatively charged CdIn2S4 NSs
were chosen as the assembly units for electrostatic selfassembly buildup. The surface-charge properties of CsPbBr3
QDs and CdIn2S4 NSs are evidenced by their ζ potentials
(Figure S1).

2.2. Preparation of CdIn2S4/CsPbBr3 QDs Heterostructures. A total of 30 mg of CdIn2S4 NSs was dispersed in 15 mL of ethyl
acetate (EA), and ultrasonic treatment was carried out for 5 min. Then, a colloidal CsPbBr3 QDs solution (16 mg/mL) was added to

h. Ultimately, the mixture was centrifuged and then dried in a vacuum
oven (60 °C) for 1 h to attain the CdIn2S4/CsPbBr3 QDs
heterostructures. The amount of CsPbBr3 QDs solution added to
the reaction system was controlled as 0.5, 1, 2, 2.5, 3, and 4 mL for the

The enhanced photocatalytic performances of TMCs/CsPbBr3 heterostructures are attributed to the
abundant active sites on the TMC frameworks, excellent light absorption of CsPbBr3 QDs, and well-defined 2D/0D heterostructures
of TMCs/CsPbBr3 QDs photosystems, which synergistically boosts the directional charge transport from CsPbBr3 QDs to TMCs,

photosystems for solar-to-fuel conversion.

question: What solvent system is used for the photocatalysis?
gold_evidence_text:
When
lactic acid or triethanolamine was used as a hole-trapping
agent, a large amount of hydrogen was generated (Figure S15),
which is a competitive reaction of CO2 reduction to CO. This
reduces not only the CO reaction rate but also the selectivity of
CO2 reduction. Therefore, in our work, ethylene glycol was
used as the hole scavenger. Furthermore, note that a large
amount of water in the Na2S and Na2SO3 aqueous solution
causes the CsPbBr3 QDs ingredient in the heterostructure to
lose catalytic activity and thus retards CO2 reduction. As shown in Figure 4d, the action spectrum of CdIn2S4/
CsPbBr3-2.5 verifies the predominant role of band-gap
photoexcitation of a CdIn2S4 substrate. A
13C isotope
experiment was performed to directly trace the carbon source
of the product.

question: What products are formed during the photocatalytic process?
gold_evidence_text:
(2) The photogenerated
electrons and holes separate and transfer to the surface of the
photocatalyst. (3) CO2 is captured and activated on the surface
of the photocatalyst. (4) The photogenerated electrons
transfer to the active sites on the photocatalyst surface to
reduce the CO2 adsorbed, while the holes are quenched by a
sacrificial agent. (5) The reaction products desorb from the
active sites.53
The photocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction may follow a
carbene path: CO2 →CO →•C →•CH3 →CH3OH/CH4,
wherein CO is an important intermediate, and its production is
dependent on the binding mode of CO on the catalyst surface. When the binding ability between C atom and the catalyst
surface is not strong, CO will be the final product.54 In terms
of the coordination mode of carbon (Figure 6), it is difficult for
the surface C atoms to hydrogenate.

question: Does the article present a list of reagents used in the synthesis?
gold_evidence_text:
Ti3AlC2 powder using an HCl−HF solution, which was
subsequently delaminated into monolayered nanosheets
(MXene) via probe sonication (Scheme 1).19,25 Gradient
centrifugation was used to collect MXene monolayered ﬂakes
by removing the multilayered Ti3C2Tx which settled to the
bottom. To ensure sure no water remained in MXene
nanosheets that could potentially degrade CsPbBr3 NCs, the
MXene nanosheets were washed and puriﬁed by dispersing and
centrifuging them with DMF and toluene alternately three
times before being dried in a vacuum oven for 24 h.

question: What amounts of metal precursors were applied in the synthesis? Check also in SI and state if it in the SI.
reference_answer:
1) PbBr2 (69 mg)
2) MXene nanosheets (10, 20, 30, 50 mg)
3) CsOA (0.4 mL, 0.125 M in ODE)
4) Ti3C2Tx (Ti3C2)
gold_evidence_text:
CsPbBr3/MXene nanocomposites were fabricated by growing CsPbBr3 nanocrystals on MXene nanosheets at a certain
molar ratio using a modiﬁed in situ growth protocol.12 It is
hypothesized that the preferential surface terminations such as
ﬂuorine, oxygen, and hydroxyl groups on the MXene are
inclined to interact with OA/OLA, by forming kinetically
favorable nucleation points for capturing PbBr2 precursors. The expected nanocrystals will grow at the nucleation sites
while consuming the cesium and PbBr2 precursors in the
solution.33 In a typical procedure, PbBr2 (69 mg), oleic acid
(OA, 0.30 mL), and oleylamine (OLA, 0.30 mL) were
predissolved in ODE (5 mL) at 150 °C.

The MXene
nanosheet (10, 20, 30, or 50 mg) suspensions in DMF (1
mL) were then injected into the above ODE solution under a
N2 atmosphere, followed by the addition of cesium oleate (0.4
mL, 0.125 M in ODE) under vigorous stirring. The reaction
was quenched after 10 s, and then subjected to three to ﬁve
cycles of centrifugation/redispersion in hexanes. The nonbound NCs in the system were easily puriﬁed and removed by
centrifugation, while the NCs adhered to the MXene
nanosheets were isolated as precipitates from the reaction
mixture and dried in vacuum overnight before use.22 The
resulting composites were named as CsPbBr3/MXene-n (n =
10, 20, 30, 50), with n corresponding to the diﬀerent amount
of MXene used for the synthesis, respectively.

question: What is the morphology and structure of halide perovskite?
reference_answer: after the selective etching of Al atoms from Ti3AlC2, SEM showes a fanned-out multilayered Ti3C2Tx
gold_evidence_text:
The morphologies of the as-prepared multilayered Ti3C2Tx
and monolayered Ti3C2Tx (MXene) nanosheets were analyzed
by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission
electron microscopy (TEM). Figure 1a showed the SEM image
of a fanned-out multilayered Ti3C2Tx after the selective etching
of Al atoms from Ti3AlC2, which was further conﬁrmed in
Figure S1. The energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping
images of oxygen (O), titanium (Ti), and ﬂuorine (F) of the
multilayered Ti3C2Tx samples showed no signals from
aluminum (Al), implying successful etching (Figure S2).19

electron-transparent foils with thin, smooth surfaces and
diameters ranging from 100 nm to several micrometers (Figure
1b).

question: Provide the specific excitation and emission wavelengths for the halide perovskite.
reference_answer:
Excitation: Not provided
Emission: 522 nm (CsPbBr3), 515 nm (CsPbBr3/MXene-10), 496 nm (CsPbBr3/MXene-50)
gold_evidence_text:
For comparison, the
PL spectrum of the free CsPbBr3 NCs exhibited a strong
emission peak at 522 nm, and the full width at half-maximum
(fwhm) was a relatively narrow 21 nm.1 However, when 10 mg
of MXene was used, the corresponding emission peak of the
CsPbBr3/MXene-10 nanocomposites was weakened and the
photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY) was decreased
from 86% for the pure CsPbBr3 NCs to 27% for the composite,
implying an obvious photoluminescence quenching eﬀect.

In
addition, no new prominent photoluminescence peaks
appeared, nor were any changes corresponding to MXene
observed in the PL spectra of CsPbBr3 NCs/MXene
nanocomposites, which clearly ruled out the energy transferinduced quenching mechanism.22 Thus, this quenching
phenomenon was attributed to the transfer of photogenerated
carriers between CsPbBr3 NCs and MXene.12,21,24 CsPbBr3/
MXene-10 exhibited an obvious blue shift from 522 to 515 nm
(Figure 4c) compared to the free NCs, possibly attributed to
the Burstein−Moss eﬀect.34,35 As the MXene content
increased successively, PL intensity decreased monotonically
(the corresponding PLQYs decreased to 11% for CsPbBr3/
MXene-20 and less than 5% for CsPbBr3/MXene-30/50),
accompanied by a consistent PL blue shift.

Speciﬁcally, the
emission peak of CsPbBr3/MXene-50 shifted from 522 to 496
nm, similar to that reported for NCs on GO,21 while the
maximum photoluminescence quenching eﬃciency exceeds
more than 90%. The photoluminescence quenching and blue shift indicate
intimate integration and interaction between the CsPbBr3 NCs
and MXene nanosheets. Time-resolved photoluminescence
(TRPL, Figure 4d) measurements were further carried out to
study the quenching eﬀect between CsPbBr3 NCs and MXene
nanosheets. The decay traces were ﬁtted using a twoexponential decay model,12 and the parameters were listed in
Table S1. Compared against the PL lifetime (τave) of the free
CsPbBr3 NCs at 18.8 ns, the PL lifetime decreased to 4.1, 1.7,
0.27, and 0.21 ns for CsPbBr3/MXene-10, CsPbBr3/MXene20, CsPbBr3/MXene-30, and CsPbBr3/MXene-50, respectively.

question: State the application of the material.
gold_evidence_text:
perovskite NC-based heterostructures has remained unexplored. Herein, we demonstrate a facile strategy for constructing
CsPbBr3/MXene nanocomposites by growing CsPbBr3 NCs
onto MXene nanosheets, yielding uniform dispersion of
CsPbBr3 NCs and tunable PL. The charge transfer properties
of the nanocomposites with various ratio of CsPbBr3 NCs and
MXene nanosheets were studied using time-resolved photoluminescence (TRPL) spectroscopy and decay lifetime
measurements. The resulting CsPbBr3/MXene nanocomposites have demonstrated enhanced performance in photodetection of visible light and X-ray illumination, and
photocatalytic reduction of CO2.

question: What solvent system is used for the photocatalysis?
gold_evidence_text:
The eﬃcient charge transfer in CsPbBr3 NCs/MXene-20
nanocomposite under excitation prompted us to test its
viability for photocatalytic CO2 reduction. The proof-ofconcept experiment was carried out in a sealed reaction vessel
under simulated solar light illumination (300 W Xe lamp with
a cut oﬀﬁlter >420 nm). Ethyl acetate was chosen as the
solvent as CO2 is highly soluble in ethyl acetate, and the
CsPbBr3 NCs remain stable in ethyl acetate due to its mild
polarity.21,23 Only an insigniﬁcant amount of CO originated
from photo-oxidation of ethyl acetate.21,23 After the solar
irradiation, both CO and CH4 were detected as the main
conversion products (Figure 5d), with no H2 and other
products detected, indicating a highly selective reduction of
CO2 into CO and CH4. The yields of the obtained CO and
CH4 increased linearly with time (Figure S11).

question: What reagents are used?
reference_answer:
1) Cesium acetate (Cs2CO3, 99.99%)
2) lead acetate trihydrate (Pb(CH3COO)2·3H2O, 99.998%)
3) oleic acid
4) 1-octadecene (ODE, >90.0%)
5) Octyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide ([Omim]Br, 98%)
6) Ethyl acetate (C4H8O2)
7) n-hexane (C6H14)
gold_evidence_text:
Cesium acetate (Cs2CO3, 99.99%),
lead acetate trihydrate (Pb(CH3COO)2·3H2O, 99.998%), oleic acid
(OA, AR), and 1-octadecene (ODE, >90.0%) were all purchased from
Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. 1-Octyl-3methylimidazolium bromide ([Omim]Br, 98%) was supplied by
Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. Ethyl acetate (C4H8O2, AR)
and n-hexane (C6H14, AR) were obtained from Sinopharm. Preparation of CsPbBr3 NCs. Cs2CO3 (0.16 g, 0.49 mmol), 0.5
mL of OA, and 8 mL of ODE were mixed in a reaction flask,
vacuumized for 30 min at 120 °C, and then heated under N2 at 150
°C until all Cs2CO3 dissolved to form CsOA solution. In a typical
synthesis of CsPbBr3 NCs, Pb(CH3COO)2·3H2O (0.188 mmol), 5
mL of ODE, 0.5 mL of OA, and a certain amount of [Omim]Br were
loaded into another reaction flask and heated under vacuum for 30
min at 120 °C.

question: What synthesis method was used to synthesize halide perovskite? Check also in SI and state if it in the SI.
gold_evidence_text:
Since Protesescu et al.7 first
prepared all inorganic metal halide perovskite (MHP) CsPbX3
(X = Cl, Br, I) nanocrystals (NCs) by the thermal injection
method in 2015, MHPs have shown great potential in the
photocatalytic conversion of CO2 because of their unique
properties such as a high light absorption coefficient, adjustable
band structure, long carrier diffusion length, and small exciton
binding energy.8−11 For example, Hou et al.12 have
investigated the use of size-tunable cubic CsPbBr3 quantum
dots (3−12 nm) for CO2 photocatalytic reduction, and the
formation rates of 4.3, 1.5, and 0.1 μmol g−1 h−1 for CO, CH4,
and H2, respectively, have been achieved in the presence of 8.5
nm of CsPbBr3 photocatalyst. The high activity of CsPbBr3 has
been ascribed to its suitable band energy and the efficient
separation of electron−hole carriers.

question: What is the shape and crystalline phase of the synthesized material?
reference_answer:
CsPbBr3 NCs (nIL/nPb) - cubic morphology with a
monolithic phase
gold_evidence_text:
Therefore, we can conclude that the introduction of the
imidazolium-based bromide IL in our strategy has the role of a
surface passivation ligand, the resource of a Br ion, as well as
the activator of CO2, which all together endow the CsPbBr3
NCs as a stable and efficient photocatalyst.
■CONCLUSION
In this study, we realized the efficient photocatalytic
conversion of CO2 by IL-passivated CsPbBr3 NCs, in which
the IL [Omim]Br was used simultaneously as the surface
engineering ligand, the precursor resource of the Br ion, and
the activator of CO2. In the presence of IL, the prepared
CsPbBr3 NCs adopted the cubic morphology with a
monolithic phase. At an optimal nIL/nPb ratio of 2, the
CsPbBr3 NCs exhibited PLQY as high as 90.93%, due to the
low recombination of the charge carriers verified by the higher
value of fast decay time τ1.

question: What is the material used for photocatalysis?
reference_answer:
CsPbBr3 NCs prepared with
nIL/nPb of 2
gold_evidence_text:
Evaluation of the Photocatalytic Performance of the
Prepared CsPbBr3 NCs for the CO2 Reduction. Finally, we
evaluated the overall photocatalytic performance of the ILpassivated CsPbBr3 NCs for the reduction of CO2 in a gas−
solid condition. We selected the CsPbBr3 NCs prepared with
nIL/nPb of 2 as a model because of their lower recombination of
charge carriers (the high PLQY; Figures 4 and 5) and high
stability (Figure 6). Figure 9a shows that the photocatalytic
reduction of CO2 by this IL-passivated CsPbBr3 NC gives the
eight-electron reduction product CH4 and the two-electron
reduction product CO. In addition, the product amount of
CH4 and CO almost linearly grows over a reaction time of 6 h,
indicating the material and catalytic stability of the prepared
CsPbBr3 NCs.

question: What is the amount of catalyst used for photocatalysis?
gold_evidence_text:
The photocatalytic performance of CsPbBr3 NCs for
the reduction of CO2 was carried out in a gas−solid reaction system
as described in our previous study.37 Typically, powder CsPbBr3
photocatalysts (20 mg) were spread on a quartz filter membrane (ϕ =
34 mm) that was supported by the sample holder in the center of the
reaction vessel. Then, the deionized water (3 mL) was added to the
bottom of the reaction vessel. A quartz window was then placed on
top of the vessel to seal the vessel and to introduce light onto the
photocatalysts’ surface.

question: What are the parameters of the source in photocatalysis?

For the photostability test, the dried
CsPbBr3 NCs were subjected to constant illumination (300 W Xe arc
lamp, 100 mW cm−2 (CEL-HXF-UV 300, CEAULIGHT)) at ca. 30
°C. For humidity experiments, the sample was loaded onto a support
holder in a sealed vessel, whose bottom was filled with water to
maintain an average humidity of 50% or 100% in the whole vessel by
adjusting the circulating water temperature. For the thermal stability
test, the stability of CsPbBr3 NCs was analyzed by thermogravimetric
analysis and further tested at 100 °C for 96 h. After the samples were
subjected to light, humidity, and heat, their stability was monitored by
XRD to determine if their structural integrity and phase transition
occurred. Evaluation of the Photocatalytic Performance for CO2
Reduction.

No H2 from the reduction of H2O was
observed, indicating the high preference toward the reduction
of CO2 on IL-passivated CsPbBr3. Figure 9b shows that the
product evolution rate of CO and CH4 is 24.56 and 6.66 μmol
g−1 h−1, respectively, corresponding to an electron consumption rate of 102.4 μmol g−1 h−1. The product formation
rate and electron consumption rate are much higher than that
of the previous report,12,46 demonstrating the superior catalytic
activity of our IL-passivated CsPbBr3 photocatalysts. Furthermore, an isotope tracer experiment with 13CO2 was carried
out through the analysis of GC-MS spectra, and the
appearance of 13CO (m/z = 29) and
13CH4 (m/z = 17)
signals (Figure S1) confirmed that the CO2 is indeed the
source of the product CO and CH4 in the presence of ILpassivated CsPbBr3 photocatalysts.

gold_evidence_text:
Eﬃcient Photocatalytic CO2 Reduction by the Construction of Ti3C2/
CsPbBr3 QD Composites
Yuyao Zhang, Wen Chen, Min Zhou, Guobin Miao, and Yueli Liu*
Cite This: ACS Appl. Energy Mater. 2021, 4, 9154−9165
Read Online
ACCESS
Metrics & More
Article Recommendations
ABSTRACT: Photoreduction of CO2 into useable hydrocarbon fuels has been
widely used in the energy conversion ﬁeld. However, the high carrier
recombination rate and the low conversion eﬃciency of as-prepared catalysts
greatly restrict their photocatalytic application. Herein, we synthesize Ti3C2/
CsPbBr3 quantum dot (Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 QD) composites by the method of selfassembly, which are used in the photoreduction of CO2. As a result, Ti3C2/
CsPbBr3 QD composites exhibit excellent photocatalytic activity and stability
for the photocatalytic CO2 reduction.

question: What is the title of the article?
reference_answer: Efficient Photocatalytic CO2 Reduction by the Construction of Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 QD Composites
gold_evidence_text:
Due to the
construction of the type II-2 heterojunction for Ti3C2/
CsPbBr3 QD composites, the photoinduced electrons of
Ti3C2 quickly migrate into the CBM of CsPbBr3 QDs. Therefore, this process can greatly boost the separation of
photoinduced electrons and holes. These accumulated
electrons on the surface of CsPbBr3 QDs participate in the
CO2 reduction reaction. As a result, the photocatalytic CO2
reduction performance of Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 QDs is sharply
enhanced. Utilization of a multielectron process gives a variety
of products which depend on the number of the involved
electrons.

question: What synthesis method was used to synthesize halide perovskite? Check also in SI and state if it in the SI.
gold_evidence_text:
Tetrabutylammonium hexaﬂuorophosphate (98%) was obtained from
Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd in China.
2.2. Preparation of CsPbBr3 QDs. CsPbBr3 QDs were
synthesized via a typical thermal injection method according to our
previous work.29 In a 50 mL three-neck bottle, 2 mmol PbBr2 powder
was added in 20 mL of 1-octadecene and heated to 120 °C under
stirring in an Ar atmosphere. Subsequently, 2.5 mL of oleic acid and
2.5 mL of oleylamine were added into this solution. After keeping for
30 min to fully dissolve PbBr2, it was heated to 165 °C, and 2 mL of
Cs-oleate solution (0.4 mmol of cesium acetate in oleic acid) was
added to this solution. The products were collected by tertiary
butanol and washed with tertiary butanol and n-hexane twice.
2.3. Preparation of Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 QD Composites.

gold_evidence_text:
The
purchased Ti3C2 and CsPbBr3 QDs were dispersed in hexane, and the
mixture was ultrasound-treated for 3 h to form good interfacial
interaction. The obtained Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 QD composites were
washed with hexane twice and ﬁnally dried under vacuum at 60 °C
overnight.
2.4. Characterization. The phase structures and constituents of

(Pert-Pro, PANalytical, the Netherlands) with a Cu Kα source (λ =
0.15418 nm). A ﬁeld emission scanning electron microscope (JSM5610 LVLV, JEOL Ltd) was used to observe the morphology of the
as-prepared samples. Microstructures of the samples were observed by
the high-resolution transmission electron microscope (JEM-2100F,
Japan).

question: What is the morphology and structure of halide perovskite?
reference_answer:
CsPbBr3 QDs are self-assembled on the surface of Ti3C2 nanosheets
Ti3C2 exhibits obvious irregular sheet-like and multibranched structures
gold_evidence_text:
The morphologies and microstructure of the as-prepared
samples are investigated by ﬁeld emission scanning electron
microscopy (FESEM) and high-resolution transmission
electron microscopy (HRTEM) observations. From the
FESEM images in Figure 2a, it can be seen that the asprepared Ti3C2 exhibits obvious irregular sheet-like and multibranched structures. From the HRTEM images of CsPbBr3
QDs shown in Figure 2b,c, clear lattice fringes could be
observed with a measured spacing of 0.410 nm, which is in
good agreement with the (110) crystal plane of the CsPbBr3
phase. CsPbBr3 QDs are of cubic phase, which is consistent
with the XRD pattern shown in Figure 1, and the average size
of CsPbBr3 QDs is about 8−10 nm.

question: What is the shape and crystalline phase of the synthesized material?
reference_answer: CsPbBr3 QDs in Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 - orthorhombic phase
gold_evidence_text:
The XRD pattern of CsPbBr3 QDs
shows typical peaks at 2θ of 15.2°, 21.6°, 30.6°, 34.4°, 37.8°,
43.9°, 46.7°, and 49.4°, which correspond to the (100), (110),
(200), (210), (211), (220), (300), and (310) crystal planes,
respectively. These diﬀraction peaks can be precisely attributed
to the standard XRD pattern of the CsPbBr3 phase (JCPDS no.
00-054-0752). The characteristic peaks of two phases of Ti3C2
and CsPbBr3 coexist for Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 QD composites,
which proves that Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 QD composites are
synthesized and CsPbBr3 QDs are self-assembled on the
surface of Ti3C2 nanosheets. Additionally, Ti3C2/CsPbBr3
composites show new peaks at 29°, 33°, and 48°, which
correspond to the orthorhombic phase of CsPbBr3 QDs.31,32

compared with CsPbBr3 QDs, which induces the slight redshift phenomenon for Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 QD composites. Compared with those of CsPbBr3 QDs, the decreased PL
intensity and red-shift phenomenon of Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 QD
composites imply that an interfacial interaction between
CsPbBr3 QDs and Ti3C2 exists. In order to further elucidate the spatial charge separation
eﬃciency of the as-prepared samples, the TRPL spectroscopy
is conducted (Figure 7d).

3.6. Mechanism of Photocatalytic CO2 Reduction. Based on the band positions of the CBM and VBM levels as
well as the depth of the Fermi level, the type II-2
Figure 7. Optical characters of CsPbBr3 QDs, Ti3C2, and Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 QD composites: (a) UV−vis absorption spectra, (b) transient

question: State the application of the material.
gold_evidence_text:
Because of the direction of the IEF is from
CsPbBr3 QDs to Ti3C2, the photoinduced electrons excited
from Ti3C2 migrate to CsPbBr3 QDs and participate in surface
redox reactions, while the photoinduced holes migrate to
Ti3C2. This result can be proved from XPS spectra (Figure 4a−
4f), photocurrent response curves (Figure 7b), and TRPL
spectra (Figure 7d). Herein, therefore, eﬀective charge
separation is achieved in the Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 QD composites. The explanation of photocatalytic CO2 reduction for Ti3C2/
CsPbBr3 QD composites is proposed as follows. CO2 can be
converted into CO and CH4 from thermodynamics by
photoinduced electrons. Under UV−vis light irradiation,
photoinduced electrons are excited and accumulated on the
surface of Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 QD composites.

question: What solvent system is used for the photocatalysis?
gold_evidence_text:
CO2 Photoreduction Performances. Figure 5
depicts the photoactivities and stability for CO2 reduction
under UV−vis light irradiation. In this work, ethyl acetate is
used as a hydrogen source as CsPbBr3 QDs can be stable in the
solvent of ethyl acetate because of its mild polarity, and CO2 is
highly soluble in ethyl acetate compared with H2O.18 As seen
from Figure 5a,b, the main products of CO and CH4 are
gradually increased with the light irradiation time. Obviously,
CH4 is the main product for CsPbBr3 QDs with a small
amount of the CO product. After 5 h, the total yields of CO
and CH4 are 9.589 and 88.085 μmol g−1, respectively. Ti3C2
exhibits low photocatalytic CO2 reduction with the evolution
of 21.408 μmol g−1 for CO and 59.541 μmol g−1 for CH4 after
5 h.

Time-resolved PL (TRPL) spectra were acquired by a laser
system (XperRam Ultimate, TRPL, Spirit 1040-8-SHG, Newport,
United States) with an excitation wavelength of 400 nm.
2.5. Photocatalytic CO2 Reduction Tests. The photocatalytic
performance of the as-prepared samples was evaluated through CO2
photoreduction activity tests. A gas chromatograph (PLS-SXE300C,
Beijing Perfect light Co. Ltd., China) equipped with diﬀerent
chromatographic columns was used, and the photocatalytic CO2
reduction tests were carried out in a 50 mL sealed quartz bottle at
room temperature. In this measurement, 10 mg of the photocatalyst
and approximately 25 mL of ethyl acetate were added into the 50 mL
bottle. Before the test, CO2 was continuously pumped into the
solution for 15 min, Ar was pumped into the above solution for 20
min to desorb O2, H2O, and other gases, and then, the bottle was
reﬁlled with CO2.

question: What is the production rate of CO?
gold_evidence_text:
Especially, the generation rate of CO
(17.98 μmol h−1 g−1) for Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 QD composites is 9.37 times higher
than that of CsPbBr3 QDs (1.92 μmol h−1 g−1), and 97.35% of the activity is
still retained after three consecutive cycles. The improved photocatalytic
performance is mainly attributed to the construction of the type II-2
heterojunction as the built internal electric ﬁeld (IEF) in the p−n junction
could accelerate the separation for both photoinduced holes and electrons. Therefore, this work provides an insight into the construction of heterojunction photocatalysts with halide perovskite QD materials
for photocatalytic applications. KEYWORDS: Ti3C2, CsPbBr3 quantum dots, heterojunction, photocatalytic CO2 reduction, type II-2 heterojunction
1.

question: What is the yield of product CH4 during photocatalysis?
reference_answer:
CsPbBr3 QDs - 88.085  μmol/g
Ti3C2 - 59.541 μmol/g                     Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 - 96.545 μmol/g
gold_evidence_text:
CO2 Photoreduction Performances. Figure 5
depicts the photoactivities and stability for CO2 reduction
under UV−vis light irradiation. In this work, ethyl acetate is
used as a hydrogen source as CsPbBr3 QDs can be stable in the
solvent of ethyl acetate because of its mild polarity, and CO2 is
highly soluble in ethyl acetate compared with H2O.18 As seen
from Figure 5a,b, the main products of CO and CH4 are
gradually increased with the light irradiation time. Obviously,
CH4 is the main product for CsPbBr3 QDs with a small
amount of the CO product. After 5 h, the total yields of CO
and CH4 are 9.589 and 88.085 μmol g−1, respectively. Ti3C2
exhibits low photocatalytic CO2 reduction with the evolution
of 21.408 μmol g−1 for CO and 59.541 μmol g−1 for CH4 after
5 h.

Compared with Ti3C2 and CsPbBr3 QDs, Ti3C2/CsPbBr3
QD composites have a much higher yield for both CO and
CH4, and the reduction yields of CO2 to CO and CH4 after 5 h
are of 89.876 and 96.545 μmol g−1, respectively. It should be
noted that the selectivity of CH4 for Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 QD
composites is almost 81.12% and the yield of CO increases to
be 4.20 times and 9.37 times that of Ti3C2 and CsPbBr3 QDs,
respectively. The reason for the CO yield increase lies in the
fact that the absorption ability of CO2 on the surface of Ti3C2/
CsPbBr3 QD composites may be enhanced and the desorption
properties of CO become easily duo to the possible synergistic
eﬀect between Ti3C2 and CsPbBr3 QDs, as the formation of
novel 2D/0D heterostructure of Ti3C4/CsPbBr3 QD composites may favor for the desorption of CO.

question: What is the production rate of CH4?
gold_evidence_text:
At ﬁrst, Ti3C2/CsPbBr3
QD composites exhibit superior light absorbance compared to
Ti3C2 and CsPbBr3 QDs, which may excite more photoinduced electrons and holes. The heterojunction construction
of Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 QD composites could eﬀectively suppress
the recombination of the photogenerated electron−hole pairs
to favor the conversion of CO2 to CO. Additionally, the large
surface character of 2D Ti3C2 may provide enough surface sites
for the loading of plenty of 0D CsPbBr3 QDs, which enables a
unique 2D/0D construction to make full use of the active sites.
4. CONCLUSIONS
In summary, novel Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 QD composites with
superior photocatalytic CO2 reduction are constructed via
the self-assembly method. Ti3C2/CsPbBr3 QD composites
exhibit excellent photocatalytic CO2 reduction performance
(17.98 μmol h−1 g−1 for CO and 19.31 μmol h−1 g−1 for CH4).

question: What is the yield of product H2 during photocatalysis?
gold_evidence_text:
This is because the cooling treatment may change the cubic
CsPbBr3 QDs to the orthorhombic structure during the selfassembly process and the temperature is below 10 °C in our
work. According to the previous report, the orthorhombic CsPbBr3
QDs exhibit sharp absorption at 527 nm, indicating a band gap
of 2.35 eV, which is quite similar to that of the cubic CsPbBr3
QDs (2.41 eV) in our case4 as the band gap is directly related
to the light absorption and the generation of photoinduced
electrons. Moreover, the orthorhombic CsPbBr3 QDs are
proven to possess the piezoelectric property, which demonstrates the promising optoelectronic application of the piezophototronic eﬀect, instead of the cubic CsPbBr3 QDs.32
Therefore, we think that the existence of the orthorhombic
CsPbBr3 QDs almost has no obvious inﬂuence on the
photocatalytic performance compared with that of cubic
CsPbBr3 QDs.
